articles.title: Climate Crisis in Pakistan
articles.summary: Pakistan is one of the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world, despite contributing less than 1% to global greenhouse gas emissions. The devastating floods of 2022, which affected more than 33 million people, serve as a stark reminder of this vulnerability. Human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, continue to release greenhouse gases, which accelerate global warming.

articles.title: Europe bakes in summer's first heatwave as continent warms
articles.summary: Europe is bracing itself for its first heatwave of the northern hemisphere summer. In Italy, 17 cities were put on red alert for high temperature, with peaks of 39 degrees Celsius (12 degrees Fahrenheit). In Rome, tourists and pilgrims went to the public fountains for refreshment, and in Venice, visitors to Jeff Bezos's wedding sweltered in the extreme heat.

articles.title: UK heatwave: Why do our cities get so hot?
articles.author: Ben Rich
articles.summary: Temperatures are higher in urban areas during heatwaves because of the urban heat island effect. Cities are on average 4-6C (39-43F) warmer than surrounding areas. In extreme cases the difference can be as much as 10C (50F). Urban heat islands are caused by hard, dark-coloured surfaces that absorb the Sun's energy rather than reflecting it. Cities have less vegetation and fewer water sources so the ground and the air heat up more readily.

articles.title: Urban flooding grips Karachi as monsoon rains continue
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Karachi remains paralysed as heavy monsoon rains continue for the third consecutive day. Several low-lying neighbourhoods in the port city have witnessed significant water accumulation, casting doubt over earlier assurances of monsoon readiness. The Pakistan Meteorological Department has forecast intermittent rain for Sunday, with chances of moderate to isolated heavy downpours in parts of the city.
